physDesc.p: The letter is of two pages and is typed. In the first page, a part of the first line is cut off.

div.p: You were a trump to let me to let me correct a few slight errors in that paragraph. It seemed to me that you made me say that Imagism derived from Poe and Whitman, and, by my bankrupting telegram, you will now see how where it did and how when it didn't. Your contention about the Greek Anthology is well taken, I will include it in future.

As your paragraph read, it made me consider the start- ing of "Poetry" to be directly responsible for the New Movement. Of course I did not mean that, for the poets were already writing or "Poetry" would have had nothing to make its hit with- Therefor to suggest that Ezra and Co. were experimenting as early as 1910, is beside the point; for we were all experimenting. You make me say tacitly that "Poetry" introduced all the important poets of the New Movement, whereas, as you will see from my telegram, it didn't. And I do not think it would be fair to those other editors & publishers who gave us an opening, to have the paragraph as it stands. At least, as it stands, it mis-quotes me, I am rather sorry you say that I confine my discussion of Imagism "Chiefly to the group represented in the Houghton-

pb.p: Mifflin Anthologies” After all, who else is there? Ezra calls himself a Vorticist, & he carefully did not call his Anthology Imagist. As he withdrew himself voluntarily, I don't see why you are so desirous of pushing him back. Of course, there are a great many other people writing Imagist verse. Because Imagism is a real aesthestic movement, like Impressionism. I hope there will always be Imagistic verse & to a certain extent there always has been - but the little group to which I belong has banded itself together under this appellation (wrongly spelt, I know) and with the with- drawal of Ezra, has the right to be considered as the principal exponents today of these tenets, it seems to me. One thing I do beg, dear Harriet, do criticize our work when you review the new Anthology, not our differences with Ezra, which, as I have told you a hundred times, were not of our making.

Witter Bynner seems to have had a beautiful time slang- ing us in Chicago. I had an interview with him in the "Tribune" Lord, how sick I am of being slanged! Nobody regrets the scizm (how do you spell it?) between the two kinds of poetry more than I do, & at least I am proud to say that I have never descended to personal invection of the other camp.
It is lovely here now, with the tulips out, & the lilacs just comings I wish you could see it. Mrs Aldis is to be in these parts next week, she tells me, so I shall hear all the Chicago news-
